Issues

Jonas Förster & Jürgen Pahle

2017-09-06

Initial Setup

library(tidyverse)
library(CoRC)

Reliably setting values

I don’t understand how to consistently keep the math up to date with the values set in the model.

For reaction parameter, my methods are currently broken. I can set the value, but after running a task the value will be restored.

loadExamples(1)
#> [[1]]
#> # A copasi model reference:
#> Model name: "The Brusselator"
#> Number of compartments: 1
#> Number of species: 6
#> Number of reactions: 4
ts1 <- runTimeCourse()
getParameters("(R1).k1")$value
#> [1] 1
setParameters("(R1).k1", value = 99)
getParameters("(R1).k1")$value
#> [1] 99
ts2 <- runTimeCourse()
getParameters("(R1).k1")$value
#> [1] 1
identical(ts1, ts2)
#> [1] TRUE
unloadModel()

In this example, the approach used for setting species values is probably not the right one:

model()$updateInitialValues(changedObjects)

Checking validity of quantity unit doesn’t work

CUnit <- CoRC:::CUnit

The CUnit class can be used for testing if user specified input is valid

ms <- CUnit("ms")
s <- CUnit("ms * 1e3")
mmol <- CUnit("mmol")
mol <- CUnit("mmol * 1e3")
mMol <- CUnit("mMol")

ms$buildExpression()
s$buildExpression()
mmol$buildExpression()
mol$buildExpression()
mMol$buildExpression()

CUnit$getExpression() shows what Copasi makes of the input.

ms$getExpression()
#> [1] "ms"
s$getExpression()
#> [1] "1000*ms"
mmol$getExpression()
#> [1] "mmol"
mol$getExpression()
#> [1] "1000*mmol"
mMol$getExpression()
#> [1] "?"

CUnit$isUnitType(“<type>”) will return useful information on validity for all but “quantity”.

ms$isUnitType("time")
#> [1] TRUE

s$isUnitType("time")
#> [1] TRUE
s$isUnitType("quantity")
#> [1] FALSE

mmol$isUnitType("quantity")
#> [1] FALSE

mol$isUnitType("quantity")
#> [1] FALSE
mol$isUnitType("time")
#> [1] FALSE
mol$isUnitType("volume")
#> [1] FALSE
mol$isUnitType("area")
#> [1] FALSE
mol$isUnitType("length")
#> [1] FALSE

mMol$isUnitType("quantity")
#> [1] FALSE

Function naming is lacking a cohesive concept

Quantity accessors are named:

getSpecies()
setSpecies()
getGlobalQuantities()
setGlobalQuantities()
setParameters()

Task related functions are named:

runTimeCourse()
runSteadyState()
runParamEst()
setTimeCourseSettings()
setSteadyStateSettings()
setParamEstSettings()

There are further functions which with awkward names:

# Adds FitItem to parameter estimation task
# No relation to setParameters(), which handles reaction parameters
addParameter()

Naming so far has been based on the desire to stay as close to the GUI as possible. It’s probalby time to define a cohesive concept.

Saving .cps loses experimental data

I commonly want to save a .cps to a tmp folder but when I do that experimental data paths will fail.

# Load example which has experimental data.
datamodel <- loadExamples(4)[[1]]

fitproblem <- as(datamodel$getTask("Parameter Estimation")$getProblem(), "_p_CFitProblem")
filenames <- fitproblem$getExperimentSet()$getFileNames()

The filenames are in the correct folder.

filenames
#> [1] "/usr/local/lib/R/3.4/site-library/CoRC/extdata/test_paramest_exp_data.txt"
file.exists(filenames)
#> [1] TRUE

Now I will save the model into a tmp folder.

file <- tempfile(fileext = ".cps")
saveModel(file)
unloadModel()

datamodel <- loadModel(file)
fitproblem <- as(datamodel$getTask("Parameter Estimation")$getProblem(), "_p_CFitProblem")
filenames <- fitproblem$getExperimentSet()$getFileNames()

The filenames are now supposedly in the folder where the .cps was saved but there they don’t exist.

filenames
#> [1] "/private/var/folders/4b/hp0s7q1x1dg62t1m8nn8y3mw0000gn/T/RtmpU8B2Be/test_paramest_exp_data.txt"
file.exists(filenames)
#> [1] FALSE
unloadModel()
invisible(file.remove(file))
